titleStmt.title: A speech made in the House of Peeres. By the Right Honourable the Earle of Monmouth, on Thursday the thirteenth of Ianuary 1641 Upon the occasion of the present destractions, and of his Majesties removall from White-hall. VVith the humble petition of the inhabitants of the county of Buckingham, in the behalfe of Mr. Hampden, knight for the said county, and of the rest of the said members of Parliament, accused by his Majestie of treason. With his Majesties gratious answer thereunto. As also the humble petition of divers of the knights, gentlemen, clergy and and [sic] other inhabitants of the county of Sommerset. With the last true newes from Ireland.
titleStmt.author: Monmouth, Henry Carey, Earl of, 1596-1661.

With his Majesties gratious answer thereunto. As also the humble petition of divers of the knights, gentlemen, clergy and and [sic] other inhabitants of the county of Sommerset. projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A SPEECH Made in the Hou≈øe of PEERES.
By the right Honorable the Earle of Monmouth, on Thur≈øday the Thirteenth of Ianuary 1641.
Vpon the occa≈øion of the pre≈øent de≈øtractions, and of his Maje≈øties removall from White-hall.

With the Humble Petition of the Inhabitants of the County of Buckingham, In the behalfe of Mr. Hampden, Knight for the ≈øaid County, and of the re≈øt of the ≈øaid members of Parliament, accu≈øed by his Maje≈øtie of Trea≈øon.
With his Maje≈øties gratious an≈øwer thereunto.
As al≈øo the Humble Petition of divers of the Knights, Gentlemen, Clergy and and other Inhabitants of the County of SOMMERSET.
With the la≈øt true newes from Ireland.

div.head: A Speech made in the Hou≈øe of Peeres, by the Right Honorable Earle of Monmouth on Thur≈øday the the 13. of Ianuary. 1641.
div.p: I Shall de≈øire to be heard ≈øpeake a few wordes, which I would much rather have heard ≈øpoken by any of your Lord≈øhips, that ≈øo they might have a happier and a more hand≈øome expre≈ø≈øion; though with a better heart, and clearer intentions they could not have beene ≈øpoken.

The ≈øad condition wee are now in (my Lords) is ≈øuch as is too apparent to any man, who hath but halfe an eye: the City of London is full of jealou≈øies & apprehen≈øions, wee fit not here free from feares; the King hath with-drawne him≈øelfe from hence, together with his Queene and children, out of a beleife, (as I conceive) that his Maje≈øties Per≈øon was not fafe here. While things continue in this po≈øture (≈øay Lords) wee may well feare an impairing, wee can ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rdly hope for the bettering of affaires‚ñ™ God h ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ plac ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ s (my Lords)
in the Medium betwixt the King and his people, let us play our parts (my Lords) let us doe our duties, and di≈øcharge our con≈øciences; let us really prove, what wee are by Name, Noblemen; let us endeavour to work a perfect and a true under≈øtanding, betweene the King and his people: let us freely unbo≈øome out ≈øelves to his Maje≈øty; and de≈øire that his Maje≈øty will be plea≈øed to doe ≈øo to us; and to this end, (my Lords) which is the end of my motion, if it ≈øhall be approved of by your Lord≈øhips, I do humbly move, that by way of conference, or any other way, wee may de≈øire the Hou≈øe of Commons to joyne with us; fir≈øt in an humble petition to his Maje≈øty, that he would be graciou≈øly plea≈øed to returne to his good City of London, as the ≈øafe≈øt place we conceive for his ≈øacred Per≈øon in the≈øe di≈øtemperd times; and then that they will likewi≈øe joyne with us in a Profe≈ø≈øion or Prote≈øtation, that we will doe what in us lies to free his Maje≈øty from his feares; to take from the Citizens of London, and his Maje≈øties other ≈øubjects their jealou≈øies and apprehen≈øions; and that we will live and dye his Maie≈øties faithfull advi≈øors, coun≈øellors and Loyall Subiects.

div.head: The Humble Petition of the In habitants of the County of Buckingham.
In the behalfe of Ma≈øter Hampden Knight for the ≈øaid County, and of the re≈øt of the members of Parliament, accu≈øed by his Maje≈øtie of High Trea≈øon.
div.p: THat your petioners having by vertue of your highnes writ cho≈øen Iohn Hampden E≈øquire Knight for our Shire in who≈øe loyalty and wi≈øedome, we his Countreymen, and Neighbours have ever had good cau≈øe to coufide: how ever of late, to our no le≈ø≈øe amazement then greife, wee finde him with other members of Parliament accu≈øed of Trea≈øon, and having taken to our ≈øerious con≈øideration, the manner of their impeachments we cannot but (under your Maie≈øties favour) conceive, that it doth ≈øo oppugne the rights of Parliaments, to the miaintenance whereof our Prote≈øtation bind us: That we beleive it is the malice (which their zeale to your Maie≈øties ≈øervice, and the State, hath contracted) in the enewies to your Maie≈øty, the Church, and common wealth hath occa≈øioned this fowle accu≈øation rather then any defert of theirs; who doe likewi≈øe through their ≈øides wound the iudgement and care of us your Petitioners, and others by who≈øe choice they were pre≈øented to the Hou≈øe.
Your petitioners mo≈øt humbly pray that Ma≈øter Hampden, and the re≈øt that lye under the burden of that accu≈øation may enjoy the Iu≈øt priviledges of Parliament.
div.closer: And your Petitioners will ever pray &c.

div.head: His Maie≈øties an≈øwer.
At the Court at Wind≈øor the 13 th of Ianuary. 1642.
div.p: HIs Maie≈øty being graciou≈øly plea≈øed to let all his Subiects under≈øtand his care not (knowingly) to violate in the lea≈øt degree, any of the Priviledges of Parliament, hath therefore lately by a Me≈ø≈øage ≈øent by the Lord Keeper ≈øignified; That he is plea≈øed (becau≈øe of the doubt that hath beene rai≈øed of the manner) to waive his former proceedings again≈øt the ≈øaid Ma≈øter Hampden and the re≈øt mentioned in this Petition, concerning whom his Maie≈øty intends to proceed in an unque≈øtionable way. And then his Maie≈øty ≈øaith it will appeare that hee had ≈øo ≈øufficient grounds to que≈øtion them, as hee might not in Iu≈øtice to the Kingdome, and honour to him≈øelfe have forborne; and yet his Maie≈øty had much rather that the ≈øaid per≈øons ≈øhould prove innocent, then be found guilty, how ever, hee cannot conceive that their crimes can in any ≈øort reflect upon tho≈øe his good Subiects, who elected them to ≈øerve in Parliament.

div.head: The Humble Petition of the Knights, Gentlemen, Clargy and other Inhabitants of the County of Sommer≈øet.
div.p:
THat having with great ioy of mind often heard of the pious inclination of this Honourable A≈ø≈øembly unto the Reformation of Church Government, and having of late (not without ≈øome regret) ≈øeene a Petition in the name of the Knights,
Gentlemen and others of this County, tending mo≈øt to the Confirmation of Epi≈øcopall power: We have thought it our duty likewi≈øe to rou≈øe up our affection unto Gods cau≈øe, and in all humility to lay the≈øe expre≈ø≈øions thereof at the feet of this great Councell, as being (under God) the chiefe Arbitrator betweene our ioy and ≈øorrow.

FOr the pre≈øent Church Government, of what right it is wee may not di≈øpute, pre≈øuming it to be ≈øubiect to the power of this Honourable a≈ø≈øembly; Neither doth it much import how ancient it is, or how neere the Apo≈øtles dayes, ≈øeeing we know that in the dayes of the Apo≈øtles them≈øelves, the my≈øtery of iniquity began to worke, and that by the efficatious operation of the ≈øame, the man of ≈øinne hath advanced him≈øelfe from the Epi≈øcopall chaire to the top of Antichri≈øtian Tyranny. But that this Government is the wife≈øt and mo≈øt pious that any people hath been ble≈øt withall ≈øince the Apo≈øtles days (what ever others may beleeve) we pre≈øume is no part of the Creed of this great councell; who≈øe godly zeale in purging the corruptions, and puni≈øhing the enemie of the true Church, being already in part made manife≈øt, doth give us rather a in≈øt cau≈øe to hope that God hath yet ≈øome further ble≈ø≈øing of Reformation for us, to be wrought by the ≈øame hands, In pro≈øecution whereof, if it ≈øhall enter into your hearts at this time to give a deadly wound unto that power, again≈øt which you have received ≈øo many complaints, we are ≈øure you ≈øhall not walke in an unknowne path, but ≈øuch as hath beene troden before you by almo≈øt all the Churches of God which have exchanged the ≈øuper≈øtition and bondage of Rome, for the glorious light and liberty of the Go≈øpell. Neither
may it be conceived as the lea≈øt degree of indignity offered to the ble≈ø≈øed memory of tho≈øe ancient or later Bi≈øhops who have ≈øo well de≈øerved of the Church of God both in life and death, if that Government which they have adorned by their ≈øingular piety and vertues being through the corruption and wickedne≈ø≈øe of tho≈øe which have ≈øucceeded them made intolerable, ≈øhall by your iu≈øt authority be aboli≈øhed. Or if the number and merit of learned and godly Bi≈øhops famous in their generations be pre≈øumed to be a rea≈øonable inducement for the continuation of that Government, we leave it to con≈øideration of this wi≈øe Councell, whether the great and far ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing multitude of ambitious; ungodly, and infamous Prelates, in mo≈øt Countries and Ages by-pa≈øt, be not a more effectuall motive for the extirpation of the ≈øame. Hereunto if we adde the pre≈øent experience even in the≈øe our dayes of their many in≈øolencies and ontrages again≈øt the truth and power of Godline≈ø≈øe, ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing and corrupting Gods Ordinances, Vnhollowing his day, per≈øecuting his Mini≈øters; Their late mi≈øchevous attempt to impo≈øe on us and our po≈øterity an in ≈øupportable Yoake of ≈øervitude and that which de≈øerveth the highe≈øt pitch of Zeale and all the bowels of this Honourable Senate, the notorious multitude of profane and ≈øcandalous Mini≈øters the mo≈øt active and malitious enemies unto Reformation, and the authoritie from which it is de≈øired. Wee tru≈øt that all this to gether, with much more well knowne to this Honorable A≈ø≈øembly, will be ≈øufficient to ju≈øtify the feares wee have conceiued of ≈øo dangerous a power.

WHERE FORE being per≈øwaded in our mindes, that it will be a worke acceptable unto God, of great advantage and comfort to the Churches of Chri≈øt, and no le≈ø≈øe conducing to the ≈øaftie, peace and ≈øtrength of
all His Maje≈øtis eKingdomes? wee mo≈øt humbly implore the Authority and zeale of this honuradle A≈ø≈øembly to proceed unto the full accompli≈øhment of the ≈øame; And having laid the Axe to the root of this Tree, to do unto it as to a plant which the Heauenly Father hath not planted, that neither the ≈øpreading boughes of the ≈øame may over-≈øhadow the Vineyeard of the Lord, nor the bitter fruit thereof make ≈øad the heart of the people of God any more for ever.

p.hi: THESE are the de≈øires of your most humble Petitioners, and wee are per≈øwaded, would have beene the expres≈øions of Multitudes more of true-hearted Chri≈øtians and Subiects, had there not beene ≈øome indirect practices u≈øed in ≈øoliciting the former Petion; whereby many wonne to ≈øub≈øcribe thereunto, who have ≈øit hence declared them≈øelves in the point of Epi≈øcopacie, to have beene at the doing thereof otherwi≈øe affected. Howbeit unto us it is ≈øufficient, that relying wholly on the good Providence of God, the pietie and wi≈øedome of this Honourable a≈ø≈øembly, and the ≈øincerity of our owne intentions, wee cannot want the comforts of a good hope, while we have the liberty to powre out our ≈øoules unto Almighty God to continne and encrea≈øed his favours and gracious a≈øpect towards this honourable & religious a≈ø≈øembly.

div.p: SIr Simon Harcot and the Governer of Dublin Ca≈øtle have di≈øarmed all Papi≈øts in Dublin, and have overthrowne the Rebells and killed many, ≈øo that no Rebell is to be ≈øeene within 7. miles of Dublin. The 9. of this moneth the Prote≈øtant Soldiers beate down the Ma≈ø≈øe hou≈øe in Dublin, & threatned to hang the Ma≈ø≈øe Prie≈øt, & broke down all the Images & ≈øpoyled their Trinkets. Tredath was ready to be relieved by ≈øea. That day we came away we ≈øaw the Iri≈øh make fires to rai≈øe more helpe, ≈øo their hopes will be fru≈øtrate. Corne is rea≈øonable at Dublin, con≈øidering our occa≈øions; the Ie≈øuites and roring Iri≈øh captaines would willingly be gone with the Prote≈øtants mony & goods, but we hope they ≈øhall leave their heads fir≈øt, if wee can but be ≈øupplyed gaine from England.
